creator: ultralame
title: 3D Printed Wizard Bust
description: This project involves creating a 3D printed wizard bust with customizable features like LED eyes and candle-lit hands (though the latter is discouraged due to safety concerns). It covers the process from 3D scanning and model editing to printing and final assembly.
steps: 3D scan a person using an Xbox Kinect and software like Reconstructme, paying attention to choosing an interesting pose and staying still during the scanning process.
Repair the STL file created by the scanning software using NetFabb or Geomagic to fix discontinuities in the mesh.
Add features to the repaired mesh using Rhinoceros or Tinkercad, such as holes for LEDs/candles and a base for stability, utilizing boolean operations to add, subtract, or intersect 3D objects.
Export the modified model as an STL file and print it using a 3D printer with dissolvable or breakaway support material.
If using breakaway support material, remove it manually and deburr the part.
Install LEDs in the eye sockets and a coin cell battery with resistors in a cavity in the back of the head to power the LEDs.

creator: ultralame
title: 3D Printed Wizard Bust
materials_required: Sodium hydroxide solution (if using dissolvable support material)
description: This project outlines the process of creating a 3D printed wizard bust with added features like LED eyes and optional candle-lit hands. It covers scanning, model editing, printing, and final assembly.
steps: 3D Scan yourself or someone else using an Xbox Kinect and software like ReconstructMe. Choose an interesting pose and minimize movement during the scanning process. If breakaway support material is being used, limit overhangs.
Repair the STL file generated from the 3D scan using software like NetFabb or NetFabb Cloud to fix any discontinuities in the mesh.

Import the repaired STL file into 3D modeling software like Rhinoceros or Tinkercad. Model a base for the bust, a cavity in the head for LEDs and a battery, and holes in the eyes and hands for LEDs or candles.
Use boolean operations to join the base to the scan and subtract the cavities and holes from the mesh.

Export the model as an STL file and 3D print it. If using a printer with dissolvable support material, submerge the printed part in a sodium hydroxide solution to dissolve the support. Otherwise, manually remove breakaway support structures and deburr the part.
Install LEDs into the eye sockets, connecting them to resistors and a coin cell battery within the cavity in the head.
